entities.description: Formula One is the highest class of international auto racing for single-seater formula racing cars sanctioned by the Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile (FIA). The World Drivers' Championship, which became the FIA Formula One World Championship in 1981, has been one of the premier forms of racing around the world since its inaugural season in 1950. The word formula in the name refers to the

heading: Births
txt: Naomi Osaka, Haitian-Japanese tennis player

heading: Deaths
txt: Fú Jiān, Chinese emperor (b. 337)

entities.title: Fú Jiān
entities.description: Fu Jian, courtesy name Yonggu (永固) or Wenyu (文玉), formally Emperor Xuanzhao of (Former) Qin ( 秦宣昭帝), was an emperor of the Chinese/Di state Former Qin, under whose rule the Former Qin state reached its greatest glory—destroying Former Yan, Former Liang, and Dai and seizing Jin's Yi Province, posturing to destroy Jin as well to unite China, until he was repelled at the Battle of Fei River in 383. F

heading: Deaths
txt: Lullus, archbishop of Mainz (b. 710)

entities.title: Lullus
entities.description: Saint Lullus was the first permanent archbishop of Mainz, succeeding Saint Boniface, and first abbot of the Benedictine Hersfeld Abbey.

heading: Deaths
txt: Al-Hakam II, Umayyad caliph (b. 915)

entities.title: Al-Hakam II
entities.description: Al-Hakam II also known as 'Abu al-'As al-mustansyir billah al-Hakm ibn 'Abd(أَبُو الْعَاصٍ الْمُسْتَنْصِرِ بِاللهِ الْحَكْمِ بْن عَبْدِ الرَّحْمَنِ; January 13, 915 – October 16, 976) was an Arab Caliph of Córdoba. He was the second Umayyad Caliph of Córdoba in Al-Andalus, and son of Abd-ar-Rahman III and Murjan. He ruled from 961 to 976.

heading: Deaths
txt: Fujiwara no Kenshi, Japanese empress (b. 994)

entities.title: Fujiwara no Kenshi (Sanjō)
entities.description: Fujiwara no Kenshi , also known as Empress Dowager Biwadono (枇杷殿皇太后), was an empress consort of the Japanese Emperor Sanjō.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pedro González de Lara, Castilian magnate

entities.title: Pedro González de Lara
entities.description: Pedro González de Lara was a Castilian magnate. He served Alfonso VI as a young man, and later became the lover of Alfonso's heiress, Queen Urraca. He may have joined the First Crusade in the following of Raymond IV of Toulouse, earning the nickname el Romero. At the height of his influence he was the most powerful person in the kingdom after the monarch. The preponderance of his power in Castile

heading: Deaths
txt: Shams al-Din Juvayni, Persian statesman, vizier and minister of finance of the Ilkhanate

entities.title: Shams al-Din Juvayni
entities.description: Shams al-Din Juvayni was a Persian statesman and member of the Juvayni family. He was an influential figure in early Ilkhanate politics, serving as sahib-i divan under four Mongol Ilkhans−Hulagu, Abaqa, Tekuder and Arghun Khan. In 1284, Arghun accused Shams al-Din of having poisoned the Ilkhan Abaqa, who may actually died of the effects of alcoholism; Shams al-Din was duly executed and replaced as

entities.title: Vizier
entities.description: A vizier is a high-ranking political advisor or minister in the Muslim world. The Abbasid caliphs gave the title wazir to a minister formerly called katib (secretary), who was at first merely a helper but afterwards became the representative and successor of the dapir of the Sassanian kings.

entities.title: Minister of finance
entities.description: A finance minister is an executive or cabinet position in charge of one or more of government finances, economic policy and financial regulation.

entities.title: Ilkhanate
entities.description: The Ilkhanate, also spelled Il-khanate, known to the Mongols as Hülegü Ulus was a khanate established from the southwestern sector of the Mongol Empire. The Ilkhanid realm, officially known as Iranzamin, was ruled by the Mongol House of Hulagu. Hulagu Khan, the son of Tolui and grandson of Genghis Khan, inherited the Middle Eastern part of the Mongol Empire after his brother Möngke Khan died in 12

heading: Deaths
txt: Amadeus V, count of Savoy (b. 1249)

entities.title: Amadeus V, Count of Savoy
entities.description: Amadeus V, surnamed the Great for his wisdom and success as a ruler, was the Count of Savoy from 1285 to 1323. He established Chambéry as his seat. He was the son of Thomas II of Savoy and Beatrice Fieschi.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nicholas V, antipope of Rome (b. 1260)

entities.title: Antipope Nicholas V
entities.description: Nicholas V, born Pietro Rainalducci was an antipope in Italy from 12 May 1328 to 25 July 1330 during the pontificate of Pope John XXII (1316–1334) at Avignon. He was the last antipope set up by a Holy Roman Emperor.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anne of Gloucester, English noblewoman (b. 1383)

entities.title: Anne of Gloucester
entities.description: Anne of Gloucester, Countess of Stafford was the eldest daughter and eventually sole heiress of Thomas of Woodstock, 1st Duke of Gloucester, by his wife Eleanor de Bohun, one of the two daughters and co-heiresses of Humphrey de Bohun, 7th Earl of Hereford, 6th Earl of Essex (1341–1373) of Pleshy Castle in Essex.

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis the Child, king of Sicily (b. 1338)

entities.title: Louis, King of Sicily
entities.description: Louis the Child was King of Sicily from 15 September 1342 until his death. He was a minor upon his succession, and was under a regency until 1354. His actual rule was short, for he died in an outbreak of plague the next year. His reign was marked by civil war.

heading: Deaths
txt: Luca Signorelli, Italian painter (b. c.1450)

entities.title: Luca Signorelli
entities.description: Luca Signorelli was an Italian Renaissance painter who was noted in particular for his ability as a draftsman and his use of foreshortening. His massive frescoes of the Last Judgment (1499–1503) in Orvieto Cathedral are considered his masterpiece.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lucas Cranach the Elder, German painter and engraver (b. 1472)

entities.title: Lucas Cranach the Elder
entities.description: Lucas Cranach the Elder was a German Renaissance painter and printmaker in woodcut and engraving. He was court painter to the Electors of Saxony for most of his career, and is known for his portraits, both of German princes and those of the leaders of the Protestant Reformation, whose cause he embraced with enthusiasm. He was a close friend of Martin Luther. Cranach also painted religious subjects

heading: Deaths
txt: Hugh Latimer, English bishop and saint (b. 1487)

entities.title: Hugh Latimer
entities.description: Hugh Latimer was a Fellow of Clare College, Cambridge, and Bishop of Worcester during the Reformation, and later Church of England chaplain to King Edward VI. In 1555 under the Catholic Queen Mary I he was burned at the stake, becoming one of the three Oxford Martyrs of Anglicanism.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nicholas Ridley, English bishop and martyr (b. 1500)

heading: Deaths
txt: Gregory XIV, pope of the Catholic Church (b. 1535)

entities.title: Pope Gregory XIV
entities.description: Pope Gregory XIV, born Niccolò Sfondrato or Sfondrati, was head of the Catholic Church and ruler of the Papal States from 5 December 1590 to his death in 1591.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Allen, English cardinal (b. 1532)

entities.title: William Allen (cardinal)
entities.description: William Allen, also known as Guilielmus Alanus or Gulielmus Alanus, was an English Cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church. He was an ordained priest, but was never a bishop. His main role was setting up colleges to train English missionary priests with the mission of returning secretly to England to keep Roman Catholicism alive there. Allen assisted in the planning of the Spanish Armada's attempted

heading: Deaths
txt: Jan Pieterszoon Sweelinck, Dutch organist and composer (b. 1562)

entities.title: Jan Pieterszoon Sweelinck
entities.description: Jan Pieterszoon Sweelinck was a Dutch composer, organist, and pedagogue whose work straddled the end of the Renaissance and beginning of the Baroque eras. He was among the first major keyboard composers of Europe, and his work as a teacher helped establish the north German organ tradition.

heading: Deaths
txt: François de Malherbe, French poet and critic (b. 1555)

entities.title: François de Malherbe
entities.description: François de Malherbe was a French poet, critic, and translator.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann Rudolf Stadler, Swiss clock-maker (b. 1605)

entities.title: Johann Rudolf Stadler
entities.description: Johann Rudolf Stadler was a Swiss Protestant clock-maker. He is mostly known for his life in Safavid Iran, where he worked as a prosperous watchmaker. He eventually fell victim to intrigue in relation to the death of a trespasser on his property, and was executed.

heading: Deaths
txt: Isaac van Ostade, Dutch painter and illustrator (b. 1621)

entities.title: Isaac van Ostade
entities.description: Isaac van Ostade was a Dutch genre and landscape painter.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Solomon Delmedigo, Italian physician, mathematician, and theorist (b. 1591)

entities.title: Joseph Solomon Delmedigo
entities.description: Joseph Solomon Delmedigo, also known as Yashar Mi-Qandia, was a rabbi, author, physician, mathematician, and music theorist.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Cook, English politician, Solicitor General for England and Wales (b. 1608)

entities.title: John Cook (regicide)
entities.description: John Cook was the first Solicitor General of the English Commonwealth and led the prosecution of Charles I. Following The Restoration, Cook was convicted of regicide and hanged, drawn and quartered on 16 October 1660. He is considered an international legal icon and progenitor of international criminal law for being the first lawyer to prosecute a head of state for crimes against his people.

entities.title: Solicitor General for England and Wales
entities.description: Her Majesty's Solicitor General for England and Wales, known informally as the Solicitor General, is one of the law officers of the Crown in the government of the United Kingdom. They are the deputy of the Attorney General, whose duty is to advise the Crown and Cabinet on the law. They can exercise the powers of the Attorney General in the Attorney General's absence. Despite the title, the positio

heading: Deaths
txt: Roger Boyle, 1st Earl of Orrery, Irish-English soldier and politician (b. 1621)

entities.title: Roger Boyle, 1st Earl of Orrery
entities.description: Roger Boyle, 1st Earl of Orrery, styled Lord Broghill from 1628 to 1660, was an Anglo-Irish soldier and politician who sat in the House of Commons of England at various times between 1654 and 1679. Boyle fought in the Irish Confederate Wars and subsequently became known for his antagonism towards Irish Catholics and their political aspirations. He was also a noted playwright and writer on 17th ce

heading: Deaths
txt: Raimondo Montecuccoli, Italian-Austrian field marshal (b. 1609)

entities.title: Raimondo Montecuccoli
entities.description: Raimondo Montecuccoli was an Italian-born professional soldier who served the Habsburg Monarchy. He was also a Prince of the Holy Roman Empire and Duke of Melfi, in the Kingdom of Naples.

heading: Deaths
txt: Antoine Laumet de La Mothe, sieur de Cadillac, French-American explorer and politician, 3rd French Governor of Louisiana (b. 1658)

entities.title: Antoine Laumet de La Mothe, sieur de Cadillac
entities.description: Antoine de la Mothe, sieur de Cadillac, born Antoine Laumet, was a French explorer and adventurer in New France which stretched from Eastern Canada to Louisiana on the Gulf of Mexico. He rose from a modest beginning in Acadia in 1683 as an explorer, trapper, and a trader of alcohol and furs, and he achieved various positions of political importance in the colony. He was the commander of Fort de Bu

entities.title: List of colonial governors of Louisiana
entities.description: This is a list of the colonial governors of Louisiana, from the founding of the first settlement by the French in 1699 to the territory's acquisition by the United States in 1803.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nevşehirli Damat Ibrahim Pasha, Greek politician, 139th Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire (b. 1666)

entities.title: List of Ottoman Grand Viziers
entities.description: The Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire was the de facto prime minister of the sultan in the Ottoman Empire, with absolute power of attorney and, in principle, dismissible only by the sultan himself in the classical period, before the Tanzimat reforms, or until the 1908 Revolution. He held the imperial seal and could convene all other viziers to attend to affairs of the state in the Imperial Counci

heading: Deaths
txt: Sylvius Leopold Weiss, German lute player and composer (b. 1687)

entities.title: Sylvius Leopold Weiss
entities.description: Sylvius Leopold Weiss was a German composer and lutenist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gerard Majella, Italian saint (b. 1725)

entities.title: Gerard Majella
entities.description: Gerard Majella, C.Ss.R., was an Italian lay brother of the Congregation of the Redeemer, better known as the Redemptorists, who is honored as a saint by the Catholic Church.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Fergusson, Scottish poet (b. 1750)

entities.title: Robert Fergusson
entities.description: Robert Fergusson was a Scottish poet. After formal education at the University of St Andrews, Fergusson led a bohemian life in Edinburgh, the city of his birth, then at the height of intellectual and cultural ferment as part of the Scottish enlightenment. Many of his extant poems were printed from 1771 onwards in Walter Ruddiman's Weekly Magazine, and a collected works was first published early in

heading: Deaths
txt: Grigory Potemkin, Russian general and politician (b. 1739)

entities.title: Grigory Potemkin
entities.description: Prince Grigory Aleksandrovich Potemkin-Tauricheski was a Russian military leader, statesman, nobleman and favourite of Catherine the Great. He died during negotiations over the Treaty of Jassy, which ended a war with the Ottoman Empire that he had overseen.

heading: Deaths
txt: Marie Antoinette, Austrian-born queen consort of Louis XVI of France (b. 1755)

entities.title: Marie Antoinette
entities.description: Marie Antoinette was the last queen of France before the French Revolution. She was born an archduchess of Austria and was the penultimate child and youngest daughter of Empress Maria Theresa and Emperor Francis I. She became dauphine of France in May 1770 at age 14 upon her marriage to Louis-Auguste, heir apparent to the French throne. On 10 May 1774, her husband ascended the throne as Louis XVI

entities.title: Louis XVI of France
entities.description: Louis XVI was the last king of France before the fall of the monarchy during the French Revolution. He was referred to as Citizen Louis Capet during the four months just before he was executed by guillotine. In 1765, upon the death of his father, Louis, Dauphin of France, he became the new Dauphin. Upon his grandfather Louis XV's death on 10 May 1774, he assumed the title King of France and Navarr

heading: Deaths
txt: John Hunter, Scottish-English surgeon and philosopher (b. 1728)

heading: Deaths
txt: Victor Amadeus III of Sardinia (b. 1726)

entities.title: Victor Amadeus III of Sardinia
entities.description: Victor Amadeus III was King of Sardinia from 1773 to his death. Although he was politically conservative, he carried out numerous administrative reforms until he declared war on Revolutionary France in 1792. He was the father of the last three mainline Kings of Sardinia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Veerapandiya Kattabomman Indian activist (b. 1760)

entities.title: Veerapandiya Kattabomman
entities.description:
Veerapandiya Kattabomman was an 18th-century Tamil Palayakarrar and chieftain 
in Tamil Nadu, India. He fought against the British East India Company and waged a war against them. He was captured by the British with the help of the ruler of the kingdom of Pudukottai, Vijaya Raghunatha Tondaiman, and at the age of 39 he was hanged at Kayathar on 16 October 1799.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nachman of Breslov, Ukrainian religious leader, founded the Breslov Hasidic group (b. 1772)

entities.title: Nachman of Breslov
entities.description: Nachman of Breslov, also known as Reb Nachman of Bratslav, Reb Nachman Breslover, Nachman from Uman, was the founder of the Breslov Hasidic movement.

entities.title: Breslov (Hasidic group)
entities.description: Breslov is a branch of Hasidic Judaism founded by Rebbe Nachman of Breslov (1772–1810), a great-grandson of the Baal Shem Tov, founder of Hasidism. Its adherents strive to develop an intense, joyous relationship with God, and receive guidance toward this goal from the teachings of Rebbe Nachman.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eva Marie Veigel, Austrian-English dancer (b. 1724)

entities.title: Eva Marie Veigel
entities.description: Eva Marie Veigel was a dancer and the wife of actor David Garrick.

heading: Deaths
txt: Théodore Barrière, French playwright (b. 1823)

entities.title: Théodore Barrière
entities.description: Théodore Barrière, French playwright, was born in Paris.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Wentworth, American journalist and politician, 19th Mayor of Chicago (b. 1815)

entities.title: John Wentworth (Illinois politician)
entities.description: John Wentworth was the editor of the Chicago Democrat, publisher of an extensive Wentworth family genealogy, a two-term mayor of Chicago, and a six-term member of the United States House of Representatives, both before and after his service as mayor.

entities.title: Mayor of Chicago
entities.description: The mayor of Chicago is the chief executive of city government in Chicago, Illinois, the third-largest city in the United States. The mayor is responsible for the administration and management of various city departments, submits proposals and recommendations to the Chicago City Council, is active in the enforcement of the city's ordinances, submits the city's annual budget and appoints city offic

heading: Deaths
txt: Haritina Korotkevich, Russian heroine (b. 1882)

entities.title: Haritina Korotkevich
entities.description: Haritina Evstafievna Korotkevich was a soldier who served in the Imperial Russian Army during the Russo-Japanese War. Volunteering to serve disguised as a man under the pseudonym Khariton Korotkevich, she soon gained a reputation as a fearless leader as a woman in her own right. She was killed by shellfire on the front line during the Siege of Port Arthur.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Leycester Lyne, English monk (b. 1837)

entities.title: Joseph Leycester Lyne
entities.description: Joseph Leycester Lyne, known by his religious name as Father Ignatius of Jesus, was an Anglican Benedictine monk. He commenced a movement to reintroduce monasticism into the Church of England.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jakub Bart-Ćišinski, German poet and playwright (b. 1856)

entities.title: Jakub Bart-Ćišinski
entities.description: Jakub Bart-Ćišinski, also known as Łužičan, Jakub Bart Kukowski, was Sorbian poet, writer and playwright, translator of Czech, Polish, Italian and German literature. He produced his works in Upper Sorbian. He is also an inventor of modern Upper Sorbian poetic language. He has been described as "the classical writer of Sorbian literature."

heading: Deaths
txt: Ralph Rose, American shot putter, discus, and hammer thrower (b. 1885)

entities.title: Ralph Rose
entities.description: Ralph Waldo Rose was an American track and field athlete. He was born in Healdsburg, California.

heading: Deaths
txt: Effie Adelaide Rowlands, British writer (b. 1859)

entities.title: Effie Adelaide Rowlands
entities.description: Effie Adelaide Maria Henderson, was a British novelist, better known under the pennames Effie Adelaide Rowlands, E. Maria Albanesi and Madame Albanesi. She was the author of more than 250 romance novels and short-stories for magazines and newspapers.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean de Brunhoff, French poet and playwright (b. 1899)

entities.title: Jean de Brunhoff
entities.description: Jean de Brunhoff was a French writer and illustrator remembered best for creating the Babar series of children's books concerning a fictional elephant, the first of which was published in 1931.

Wilhelm Frick, German lawyer and politician, German Minister of the Interior (b. 1877)
Alfred Jodl, German general (b. 1890)
Ernst Kaltenbrunner, Austrian SS officer (b. 1903)
Wilhelm Keitel, German field marshal (b. 1882)
Alfred Rosenberg, Estonian architect and politician (b. 1893)
Fritz Sauckel, German sailor and politician (b. 1894)
Arthur Seyss-Inquart, Austrian lawyer and politician, 16th Federal Chancellor of Austria (b. 1892)
Julius Streicher, German journalist and politician (b. 1887)
Joachim von Ribbentrop, German lieutenant and politician, Minister for Foreign Affairs of Germany (b. 1893)

entities.title: Nuremberg trial
entities.description: The Nuremberg trials were a series of military tribunals held after World War II by the Allied forces under international law and the laws of war. The trials were most notable for the prosecution of prominent members of the political, military, judicial, and economic leadership of Nazi Germany, who planned, carried out, or otherwise participated in the Holocaust and other war crimes. The trials we

heading: Deaths
txt: Anna B. Eckstein, German peace activist (b. 1868)

entities.title: Anna B. Eckstein
entities.description: Anna Bernhardine Eckstein was a German champion of world peace, who trained as a teacher and campaigned for peace across the world. She gathered six million signatures on a petition and, in 1913, was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize. The outbreak of the First World War interrupted her plans but her ideas influenced the Kellogg–Briand Pact of 1928.

heading: Deaths
txt: Liaquat Ali Khan, Indian-Pakistani lawyer and politician, 1st Prime Minister of Pakistan (b 1895)

entities.title: Liaquat Ali Khan
entities.description: Nawabzada Liaquat Ali Khan, widely known as Quaid-e-Millat and Shaheed-e-Millat, was a Pakistani statesman, lawyer, political theorist, and one of the leading founding fathers of Pakistan. He became the first Prime Minister of Pakistan; he also held cabinet portfolio as the first foreign, defence, and the frontier regions minister from 1947 until his assassination in 1951. Prior to the partition,

entities.title: Prime Minister of Pakistan
entities.description: The prime minister of Pakistan is the head of government of Pakistan and designated as the "Chief Executive of the Islamic Republic".

heading: Deaths
txt: Jules Rimet, French businessman (b. 1873)

entities.title: Jules Rimet
entities.description: Jules Rimet was a French football administrator who was the 3rd President of FIFA, serving from 1921 to 1954. He is FIFA's longest-serving president, in office for 33 years. He also served as the president of the French Football Federation from 1919 to 1942.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Anthony Sydney Ritson, English rugby player, mines inspector, engineer and educator (b. 1887)

entities.title: John Anthony Sydney Ritson
entities.description: John Anthony Sydney Ritson DSO & Bar, was an English mines inspector and engineer who became professor of mining at Leeds University and at the Royal School of Mines, Imperial College, London. In his early life he was a rugby union player of note playing international rugby for both England and the British and Irish Lions, and was a member of the first ever English Grand Slam winning side. During

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Redfield, American anthropologist of Mexico (b. 1897)

entities.title: Robert Redfield
entities.description: Robert Redfield was an American anthropologist and ethnolinguist, whose ethnographic work in Tepoztlán, Mexico is considered a landmark of Latin American ethnography. He was associated with the University of Chicago for his entire career: all of his higher education took place there, and he joined the faculty in 1927 and remained there until his death in 1958, serving as Dean of Social Sciences fr

heading: Deaths
txt: Minor Hall, American drummer (b. 1897)

entities.title: Minor Hall
entities.description: Minor Hall, better known as Ram Hall, was an American jazz drummer active on the New Orleans jazz scene. He was the younger brother of Tubby Hall.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Marshall, American general and politician, 3rd United States Secretary of Defense, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1880)

entities.title: United States Secretary of Defense
entities.description: The United States secretary of defense (SecDef) is the leader and chief executive officer of the United States Department of Defense, the executive department of the U.S. Armed Forces. The secretary of defense's position of command and authority over the military is second only to that of the president of the United States, who is the commander-in-chief. This position corresponds to what is genera

entities.title: Nobel Peace Prize
entities.description: The Nobel Peace Prize is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Swedish industrialist, inventor, and armaments manufacturer Alfred Nobel, along with the prizes in Chemistry, Physics, Physiology or Medicine, and Literature. Since March 1901, it has been awarded annually to those who have "done the most or the best work for fraternity between nations, for the abolition or reduction

heading: Deaths
txt: Gaston Bachelard, French poet and philosopher (b. 1884)

entities.title: Gaston Bachelard
entities.description: Gaston Bachelard was a French philosopher. He made contributions in the fields of poetics and the philosophy of science. To the latter he introduced the concepts of epistemological obstacle and epistemological break. He influenced many subsequent French philosophers, among them Michel Foucault, Louis Althusser, Dominique Lecourt and Jacques Derrida, as well as the sociologists Pierre Bourdieu and

heading: Deaths
txt: Patsy Callighen, Canadian ice hockey player (b. 1906)

entities.title: Patsy Callighen
entities.description: Francis Charles Winslow "Patsy" Callighen was a Canadian professional ice hockey player who played 36 regular season and nine playoff games in the National Hockey League. Born in Toronto, Ontario, he played with the New York Rangers.

heading: Deaths
txt: George O'Hara, American actor and screenwriter (b. 1899)

entities.title: George O'Hara (actor)
entities.description: George O'Hara was an American motion picture actor and screenwriter of the silent film era.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ellis Kinder, American baseball player (b. 1914)

entities.title: Ellis Kinder
entities.description: Ellis Raymond "Old Folks" Kinder was an American Major League Baseball pitcher with the St. Louis Browns, Boston Red Sox, St. Louis Cardinals and the Chicago White Sox between 1946 and 1957. Kinder batted and threw right-handed. He was born in Atkins, Arkansas.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robin Boyd, Australian architect and educator, designed the Domain Park Flats (b. 1919)

entities.title: Robin Boyd (architect)
entities.description: Robin Gerard Penleigh Boyd was an Australian architect, writer, teacher and social commentator. He, along with Harry Seidler, stands as one of the foremost proponents for the International Modern Movement in Australian architecture. Boyd is the author of the influential book The Australian Ugliness (1960), a critique on Australian architecture, particularly the state of Australian suburbia and its

entities.title: Domain Park Flats
entities.description: Domain Park Flats is a 20-storey residential building in Melbourne, Australia, completed in 1962. The block was designed by influential architect Robin Boyd CBE, one of the foremost proponents for the International Modern Movement in Australian architecture and recipient of the RAIA Gold Medal in 1969.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nick Begich, American lawyer and politician (b. 1932)

entities.title: Nick Begich
entities.description: Nicholas Joseph Begich Sr. was an American politician who served as a member of the United States House of Representatives from Alaska. He is presumed to have died in the crash of a light aircraft in Alaska in 1972; his body was never found.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hale Boggs, American lawyer and politician (b. 1914)

heading: Deaths
txt: Leo G. Carroll, English-American actor (b. 1886)

heading: Deaths
txt: Gene Krupa, American drummer, composer, and actor (b. 1909)

entities.title: Gene Krupa
entities.description: Eugene Bertram Krupa was an American jazz drummer, band leader and composer known for his energetic style and showmanship. His drum solo on "Sing, Sing, Sing" (1937) elevated the role of the drummer from an accompanying line to an important solo voice in the band.

heading: Deaths
txt: Vittorio Gui, Italian conductor and composer (b. 1885)

entities.title: Vittorio Gui
entities.description: Vittorio Gui was an Italian conductor, composer, musicologist and critic.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dan Dailey, American actor, singer, dancer, and director (b. 1913)

entities.title: Dan Dailey
entities.description: Daniel James Dailey Jr. was an American dancer and actor. He is best remembered for a series of popular musicals he made at 20th Century Fox such as Mother Wore Tights (1947).

heading: Deaths
txt: Johan Borgen, Norwegian author and critic (b. 1903)

entities.title: Johan Borgen
entities.description: Johan Collett Müller Borgen was a Norwegian author, journalist and critic. His best-known work is the novel Lillelord for which he was awarded the Norwegian Critics Prize for Literature in 1955. He was nominated for the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1966.

heading: Deaths
txt: Moshe Dayan, Israeli general and politician, 5th Foreign Affairs Minister of Israel (b. 1915)

entities.title: Moshe Dayan
entities.description: Moshe Dayan was an Israeli military leader and politician. As commander of the Jerusalem front in the 1948 Arab–Israeli War, Chief of Staff of the Israel Defense Forces (1953–1958) during the 1956 Suez Crisis, but mainly as Defense Minister during the Six-Day War in 1967, he became a worldwide fighting symbol of the new state of Israel. In the 1930s, Dayan joined the Haganah, the pre-state Jewish

entities.title: Foreign Affairs Minister of Israel
entities.description: The Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs is one of the most important ministries in the Israeli government. The ministry's role is to implement Israel's foreign policy, and promote economic, cultural, and scientific relations with other countries.

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Jean Shepherd
entities.description: Jean Parker Shepherd Jr. was an American storyteller, humorist, radio and TV personality, writer, and actor. He was often referred to by the nickname Shep. With a career that spanned decades, Shepherd is known for the film A Christmas Story (1983), which he narrated and co-scripted, based on his own semiautobiographical stories.

A Democrat, he was elected posthumously to the U.S. Senate; his widow, Jean, served in his stead for two years until a special election.

entities.description: The White House press secretary is a senior White House official whose primary responsibility is to act as spokesperson for the executive branch of the federal government of the United States, especially with regard to the president, senior aides and executives, as well as government policies.

entities.title: President of Peru
entities.description: The president of Peru, formally recognized as the President of the Republic of Peru, is the head of state and head of government of Peru. The president is the head of the executive branch and is the Supreme Head of the Armed Forces and Police of Peru. The office of president corresponds to the highest magistracy in the country, making the president the highest ranking public official in Peru.
